Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds George Kachergis of Indiana University to conduct a research project, entitled "Mechanisms of language learning," during the summer of 2012 at Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology in Nomi, Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Takashi Hashimoto.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is new understandings of the memory and learning mechanisms that allow infants to learn their first language. Most infants produce their first words as one-year-olds and have a vocabulary of more than 60,000 words by the end of high school. This research is developing mathematical models of how people learn from which it may be possible to identify deficits that interfere with language learning in some and find ways to better structure the learning environment to aid in learning first languages and beyond. The models are not limited to language learning because they are built upon basic mechanisms of learning and memory and can be applied to education in many domains, from memorizing anatomy to learning molecule names and structures. This type of hierarchical model can also be used to identify individual differences and may suggest ways of structuring training to keep learners from falling behind and to keep them challenged.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Working closely with Professors Hashimoto and Hidaka at the Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, I created several formal models of human language acquisition. Trained on both experimental data and transcripts of real parent-child interactions, these models aim to capture the trajectory of vocabulary learning, from childhood through adulthood, in terms of simple learning, memory, and attentional processes. In formulating the models, I gained new mathematical knowledge and learned skills that will be useful for me for decades to come. I wrote software to simulate the models, and applied them to real-world experimental data. The models we developed, based on the generalized Bradley-Terry model, are also useful for other problems involving contingency tables (e.g., word alignment for machine translation of natural languages). The first two models matched human data from some conditions well, but do not show trial-order effects that humans show in other data. We formulated a few additional models with varying attention and memory that we hope will allow us to capture these order effects, and we are continuing to work on implementing these models. We are working on a paper containing these results. Our effort synthesized previous model approaches and data, and will serve as an example and starting point for other researchers seeking to understand language acquisition. 

  These models can also be used to evaluate study strategies and to predict which structures and sequences of learning events best serve acquisition. The learning of word-object mappings is not only a problem of language learning; it likely generalizes to memorizing anatomy, molecule names and structures, and many other fields. Understanding how simple cognitive processes of memory, learning, and attention interact to produce effects over short and long sequences of learning events is of great interest to researchers in psychology and education. Having a model allows prediction based on different training, as well as parameter differences that may identify memory or attention deficits in some students. In general, it will be possible to measure an individual’s parameters and then tailor their learning experience using cognitive tutors based on the proposed models.

Finally, this project supported my development as a scientist, giving me invaluable international experience and collaborations. I gave three talks and a poster presentation during my time in Japan, and made contact with a number of researchers. The knowledge and training I gained from Professors Hidaka and Hashimoto is indispensable in my field, and I plan to pass it on to my students and colleagues as my career advances.
